p: Alphavirus infections are known to induce translational shut-off through a variety of mechanisms, including phosphorylation of eIF2α by PKR [ 44]. Even though phosphorylated eIF2α inhibits global protein synthesis, translation of alphavirus SG RNA remains unaffected [ 45]. In fact, in infected cells, SG RNA translation occurs more efficiently in the presence of eIF2α phosphorylation [ 46]. However, during early alphavirus infection, eIF2α phosphorylation appears to be inhibited by nsP4, possibly to allow accumulation of CHIKV RNA transcripts for subsequent translation [ 47].
